description: IPv6 address types, subnetting, autoconfiguration, and transition mechanisms
learningObjectives: Master IPv6 address structure and shortening rules
Identify different IPv6 address types and scopes
references: RFC 4291 - IP Version 6 Addressing Architecture
RFC 3587 - IPv6 Global Unicast Address Format
RFC 4862 - IPv6 Stateless Address Autoconfiguration
RFC 3315 - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol for IPv6

questions.question: Which of the following represents the correctly shortened form of the IPv6 address 2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000:ff00:0042:8329?
questions.explanation: IPv6 shortening rules: remove leading zeros in each quartet, and replace the longest string of consecutive zero quartets with :: (only once per address). 2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000:ff00:0042:8329 becomes 2001:db8::ff00:42:8329.
hints: Remove leading zeros from each quartet
Replace the longest consecutive zeros with double colon (::)
Double colon can only be used once per address
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.2 - Text Representation of Addresses

questions.question: What is the full expanded form of the IPv6 address fe80::1?
questions.explanation: The :: represents consecutive zero quartets. In fe80::1, the :: replaces six zero quartets (0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000), resulting in fe80:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0001.
hints: Double colon represents consecutive zero quartets
Count how many quartets are missing
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.2 - Text Representation of Addresses

questions.question: Which IPv6 address type is used for link-local communications and is automatically configured on all IPv6-enabled interfaces?

answer.correct: Link-Local (fe80::/10)

questions.explanation: Link-Local addresses (fe80::/10) are automatically configured on all IPv6-enabled interfaces and are used for communication within the same network segment. They are not routable beyond the local link.
hints: Automatically configured on every IPv6 interface
Not routable beyond the local network segment
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.4 - Address Type Identification
RFC 4862 - Stateless Address Autoconfiguration

questions.question: In IPv6, what does the /64 prefix length represent in most network scenarios?
options: 64 bits for network, 64 bits for host identification

answer.correct: 64 bits for network, 64 bits for host identification

questions.explanation: /64 means the first 64 bits identify the network prefix, and the remaining 64 bits identify the interface (host). This is the standard subnet size for most IPv6 networks and enables SLAAC and EUI-64 autoconfiguration.
hints: Standard subnet boundary for most networks
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.5.1 - Interface Identifiers
RFC 3587 - IPv6 Global Unicast Address Format

questions.question: Which IPv6 address is used as the loopback address, equivalent to 127.0.0.1 in IPv4?
questions.explanation: ::1 is the IPv6 loopback address, equivalent to IPv4's 127.0.0.1. It represents 0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0001 and is used for local communication within the same device.
hints: Only one address, not a range like IPv4
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.5.3 - The Loopback Address

questions.question: Given the MAC address 00:1b:63:84:45:e6, what would be the EUI-64 interface identifier for IPv6 autoconfiguration?
questions.explanation: EUI-64 process: 1) Split MAC at 24-bit boundary: 00:1b:63 | 84:45:e6, 2) Insert fffe: 00:1b:63:ff:fe:84:45:e6, 3) Flip 7th bit (U/L bit): 00 becomes 02. Result: 021b:63ff:fe84:45e6.
hints: Split MAC address in the middle (after 3rd octet)
Flip the 7th bit (universal/local bit) of first octet
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.5.1 - Interface Identifiers
RFC 4862 Section 5.3 - Creation of Link-Local Addresses

questions.question: What is the purpose of flipping the 7th bit (U/L bit) in the EUI-64 interface identifier creation process?
options: To indicate the address is locally administered
To indicate the address is universally administered

answer.correct: To indicate the address is universally administered

questions.explanation: The 7th bit (U/L bit) indicates universal (1) vs local (0) administration. Since MAC addresses are universally administered by IEEE, flipping the bit from 0 to 1 correctly indicates the resulting interface identifier is derived from a universally administered identifier.
hints: MAC addresses are assigned by IEEE globally
The bit indicates the scope of administration
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.5.1 - Interface Identifiers
IEEE 802 - Local and Metropolitan Area Networks

questions.question: Which IPv6 multicast address is used for all IPv6 nodes on the local network segment?
questions.explanation: ff02::1 is the 'All Nodes' link-local multicast address. All IPv6-enabled devices on the local link listen to this address. ff02::2 is for all routers, ff01::1 is node-local scope, and ff05::1 is site-local scope.
hints: All multicast addresses start with ff
Used to communicate with all devices on the segment
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.7.1 - Pre-Defined Multicast Addresses

questions.question: In SLAAC (Stateless Address Autoconfiguration), what information does a host receive from Router Advertisement messages?
options: Network prefix and default gateway information

answer.correct: Network prefix and default gateway information

questions.explanation: Router Advertisement (RA) messages contain the network prefix (typically /64) and default gateway information. The host combines this prefix with its own interface identifier (often EUI-64) to create a complete global unicast address.
hints: SLAAC is 'stateless' - no central server tracks assignments
Host generates its own interface portion
Router provides network portion and gateway info
references: RFC 4862 Section 5.5.3 - Router Advertisement Processing
RFC 4861 - Neighbor Discovery for IP version 6

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of IPv6's /64 subnet standard compared to variable subnet masks in IPv4?
options: Enables automatic address configuration and simplifies network design

answer.correct: Enables automatic address configuration and simplifies network design

questions.explanation: The /64 boundary enables SLAAC, EUI-64 autoconfiguration, and simplifies network design by providing a consistent 64-bit interface identifier space. This eliminates the need for complex subnet calculations while providing 2^64 possible host addresses per subnet.
references: RFC 3587 Section 3 - Global Unicast Address Structure
RFC 4862 - IPv6 Stateless Address Autoconfiguration

questions.question: Given the IPv6 prefix 2001:db8:acad::/48, how many /64 subnets can be created?

answer.correct: 65,536 subnets

questions.explanation: From /48 to /64 provides 16 additional bits for subnetting (64-48=16). 2^16 = 65,536 possible /64 subnets. Each /64 subnet provides 2^64 host addresses, which is the standard IPv6 subnet size.
hints: /64 is the standard IPv6 subnet boundary
references: RFC 3587 Section 3 - Global Unicast Address Structure

questions.question: Which statement best describes the difference between SLAAC and DHCPv6?
options: SLAAC provides complete configuration, DHCPv6 only provides addresses
SLAAC is stateless with host-generated addresses, DHCPv6 is stateful with server-assigned addresses
SLAAC is faster, DHCPv6 is more secure
SLAAC uses EUI-64, DHCPv6 uses random identifiers

answer.correct: SLAAC is stateless with host-generated addresses, DHCPv6 is stateful with server-assigned addresses

questions.explanation: SLAAC (Stateless Address Autoconfiguration) allows hosts to generate their own addresses using router-provided prefixes. DHCPv6 is stateful, with a server assigning and tracking address assignments. Both can coexist in a network.
hints: Stateless means no server tracks assignments
Stateful means server manages and tracks addresses
Think about who generates the address
references: RFC 4862 - IPv6 Stateless Address Autoconfiguration
RFC 3315 - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol for IPv6

questions.question: What IPv6 address range is designated for Unique Local Addresses (ULA), similar to RFC 1918 private addresses in IPv4?
questions.explanation: fc00::/7 is the Unique Local Address (ULA) range in IPv6, similar to RFC 1918 private addresses in IPv4. These addresses are not routable on the global Internet but provide unique addressing within organizations.
references: RFC 4193 - Unique Local IPv6 Unicast Addresses

questions.question: In an IPv6 address 2001:db8:acad:1::1/64, which portion represents the interface identifier?
questions.explanation: In a /64 network, the first 64 bits (2001:db8:acad:1) represent the network prefix, and the last 64 bits represent the interface identifier. ::1 expands to 0000:0000:0000:0001 in the interface portion.
hints: /64 means first 64 bits are network, last 64 bits are interface
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.5.1 - Interface Identifiers

questions.question: Which ICMPv6 message type is used by routers to advertise their presence and network prefixes to hosts?

answer.correct: Router Advertisement

questions.explanation: Router Advertisement (RA) messages are sent by routers to advertise their presence, network prefixes, and other configuration parameters. Hosts use this information for SLAAC and default gateway configuration.
hints: Think about what routers send to advertise themselves
references: RFC 4861 Section 4.2 - Router Advertisement Message Format

questions.question: What happens when an IPv6 host receives a Router Advertisement with the 'M' (Managed) flag set to 1?
options: Host should use DHCPv6 for address configuration
Host should use link-local addresses only

answer.correct: Host should use DHCPv6 for address configuration

questions.explanation: The 'M' (Managed) flag in Router Advertisement messages indicates that hosts should use DHCPv6 for stateful address configuration instead of SLAAC. When M=1, hosts contact a DHCPv6 server for address assignment.
hints: Directs hosts to use DHCPv6 server
references: RFC 4861 Section 4.2 - Router Advertisement Message Format
RFC 3315 - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol for IPv6

questions.question: In dual-stack networks, what is the primary method for preferring IPv6 over IPv4 when both are available?

answer.correct: Default Address Selection Policy (RFC 6724)

questions.explanation: RFC 6724 defines the Default Address Selection Policy, which provides rules for preferring IPv6 over IPv4 in dual-stack environments. This includes source and destination address selection algorithms.
hints: Handles both source and destination selection
references: RFC 6724 - Default Address Selection for Internet Protocol version 6

questions.question: Which IPv6 transition mechanism encapsulates IPv6 packets within IPv4 packets to traverse IPv4-only networks?

answer.correct: 6to4 Tunneling

questions.explanation: 6to4 tunneling encapsulates IPv6 packets within IPv4 packets, allowing IPv6 traffic to traverse IPv4-only network infrastructure. This is one of several tunneling mechanisms for IPv6 transition.
hints: Allows IPv6 to cross IPv4 networks
references: RFC 3056 - Connection of IPv6 Domains via IPv4 Clouds

questions.question: What is the unspecified IPv6 address and when is it typically used?
options: :: - used when no address is available

answer.correct: :: - used when no address is available

questions.explanation: The unspecified address (::) indicates the absence of an address. It's used by hosts during address acquisition (like DHCP) or in routing tables to indicate a default route. It must never be assigned to any interface.
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.5.2 - The Unspecified Address

questions.question: In IPv6 Neighbor Discovery, what replaces the ARP protocol used in IPv4?
options: Neighbor Solicitation and Neighbor Advertisement messages

answer.correct: Neighbor Solicitation and Neighbor Advertisement messages

questions.explanation: Neighbor Solicitation (NS) and Neighbor Advertisement (NA) messages replace ARP in IPv6. NS messages discover link-layer addresses of neighbors, and NA messages respond with the requested information.
references: RFC 4861 Section 4.3 - Neighbor Solicitation Message Format
RFC 4861 Section 4.4 - Neighbor Advertisement Message Format

questions.question: Given the IPv6 global unicast address 2001:db8:cafe:1::1/64, what would be the corresponding solicited-node multicast address?
questions.explanation: Solicited-node multicast addresses are formed by taking ff02::1:ff00:0000 and appending the last 24 bits of the unicast address. For 2001:db8:cafe:1::1, the last 24 bits are 00:00:01, giving ff02::1:ff00:0001.
hints: Take the last 24 bits (6 hex digits) of the unicast address
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.7.1 - Solicited-Node Multicast Addresses

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of IPv6 solicited-node multicast addresses?
options: To broadcast to all nodes on the network
To efficiently perform address resolution without flooding

answer.correct: To efficiently perform address resolution without flooding

questions.explanation: Solicited-node multicast addresses enable efficient address resolution in Neighbor Discovery. Instead of broadcasting to all nodes (like ARP), IPv6 multicasts to a small group of nodes that might have the target address, reducing network traffic.
hints: More efficient than broadcasting to everyone
references: RFC 4861 Section 7.2.2 - Address Resolution

questions.question: In IPv6, what is the maximum number of hops (hop limit) that can be set in the IPv6 header?
questions.explanation: The Hop Limit field in the IPv6 header is 8 bits, allowing values from 0 to 255. This replaces the TTL (Time To Live) field in IPv4 and serves the same purpose of preventing routing loops.
references: RFC 8200 Section 3 - IPv6 Header Format

questions.question: Which statement about IPv6 and NAT (Network Address Translation) is most accurate?
options: IPv6 requires NAT for internet connectivity
IPv6 eliminates the need for NAT due to abundant address space
IPv6 NAT works the same as IPv4 NAT

answer.correct: IPv6 eliminates the need for NAT due to abundant address space

questions.explanation: IPv6's vast address space (2^128 addresses) eliminates the address scarcity that necessitated NAT in IPv4. Every device can have globally unique addresses, removing the need for address translation in most scenarios.
hints: NAT was primarily needed due to IPv4 address shortage
Global unique addressing is possible with IPv6
references: RFC 4291 - IP Version 6 Addressing Architecture

questions.question: What is the standard prefix length typically assigned to end-user sites by ISPs for IPv6?
questions.explanation: Many ISPs assign /56 prefixes to residential customers and small businesses. This provides 256 /64 subnets (2^8), which is sufficient for most end-user scenarios while conserving address space compared to the traditional /48 recommendation.
hints: Provides multiple /64 subnets for end users
Balance between address space and conservation
Common ISP assignment for residential customers
references: RFC 6177 - IPv6 Address Assignment to End Sites

questions.question: In IPv6, what does it mean when a Router Advertisement message has both M=0 and O=1 flags set?
options: Use SLAAC for addresses, DHCPv6 for other configuration
Use DHCPv6 for addresses, SLAAC for other configuration

answer.correct: Use SLAAC for addresses, DHCPv6 for other configuration

questions.explanation: M=0 (Managed flag) means don't use DHCPv6 for address configuration (use SLAAC). O=1 (Other flag) means use DHCPv6 for other configuration options like DNS servers. This is called 'stateless DHCPv6'.
hints: M flag controls address configuration method
O flag controls other configuration options
references: RFC 4861 Section 4.2 - Router Advertisement Message Format
RFC 3315 - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol for IPv6

questions.question: Which IPv6 feature helps prevent address scanning attacks that are common in IPv4 networks?
options: The vast /64 subnet space making scanning impractical

answer.correct: The vast /64 subnet space making scanning impractical

questions.explanation: IPv6 /64 subnets contain 2^64 (18 quintillion) possible addresses. This makes network scanning attacks impractical as it would take an extremely long time to scan even a small portion of the address space.
hints: Think about the size of /64 address space
Time required to scan becomes prohibitive
references: RFC 7707 - Network Reconnaissance in IPv6 Networks

questions.question: What is the IPv6 equivalent of the IPv4 default route 0.0.0.0/0?
questions.explanation: The IPv6 default route is ::/0, which represents all zeros with a prefix length of 0. This matches any IPv6 destination address and serves the same purpose as 0.0.0.0/0 in IPv4 routing tables.
hints: Similar concept to IPv4 default route
references: RFC 4291 Section 2.5.2 - The Unspecified Address
